ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned a lot about Gephi and basic intro statistics
I gained insight into the formation of networks, reviewed some core math principles from high school, and learnt how to build my own network on Gephi.
Networks, niche word problems, how to use gephi.
I enhanced my skills in maths and coding
learned more about some statistics stuff and graphing with Gephi
working with Gephi
How to add, multiply, have common sense
Networks are everywhere! Just really interesting lectures.
Data
How various networks exist all around us, how they grow and shrink. Relearned basic algebra skills, econ topics
Probability, Gephi, game theory, etc
probabilities, different networks
I learned a lot about how networks work, where I could see them in real life, and I especially appreciated the game theory aspects of the course as that is something I did not know about before.
I learned about how numerical systems and networks operate.
Learned about various stochastic models and best practices in mateix, game theory and optimal market allocation scenarios.
Working Gephi was pretty tricky for our final project but wasn't too hard to work on. Learning about the networks that describes our real life interactions was pretty cool
General concepts about networks.
I gained an appreciation for a different type of data modeling applicable to my major.
I learned to analyze basic networks and use Gephi. Also some application of networks to contemporary concerns. Didn't learn a ton of new concepts, just applied them in different contexts.
Matrix operations and problem-solving related to networks

Skills in general statistics including probability theory

A great understanding of how networks work
I gained insights into networks
how to build networks

Well I still can't really define a network for you but I guess I can sorta use Gephi (but not understand the output) and use some really basic matrix operations. Can't tell ya much, but like, that's not why people take this class.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: weakness could be that it is not very engaging but lectures are straight to the point and easy to remember

Strength: The problem sets are not too difficult (although they didn't always line up with the lecture), the professor is nice, and the network projects at the end of the course are interesting and a nice opportunity for collaboration with peers. 
Weaknesses: If something was confusing going to TA office hours was not that helpful. You are kind of on your own. The midterm grading was also changed after graded had been posted which was very frustrating too.
fun and well taught

Strengths: Recorded lecture made it easy to not attend class and go at your own pace (which was nice for flexibility), Professor was super nice from the times I interacted with him, math was not too difficult but took some effort, final project was easy, we were allowed to resubmit Psets as many times until they were due which helped me understand how to actually do the problem correctly, good QR credit for people who aren't great at math.
Weaknesses: TA's were nice but usually hard to reach via email (one TA helped me on a problem and gave me the wrong approach and then never answered whenever I said it was wrong and was looking to understand how to successfully accomplish the problem), course was super disconnected (the lecture material never seemed to coincide with assignments, which was the math on the slides and that's it)

It is not very engaging or interactive. It could be more clear and more examples could be used. 
However, I like the format of doing the homework again if you are incorrect because it allows you to learn the right method without being penalised for previous attempts

Strength-- super low workload 
Weakness-- still can't quite tell you what I learned

strengths: low workload, attentive and responsive TA's
weaknesses: little feedback, and sometimes the topics were not explained well
Straightforward
Great 6th/7th/8th course

Strength: super interesting topics

Weakness: lectures can be dry and not cohesive. But more often than not classes were great
great class
Good class
Project does not have much guidance. Homework and exams are good format
lecture was too bland, monotone, etc.

This course was amazing in that I felt the instructors were truly empathetic towards the students and designed the course in such a way that I was focused on enjoying the material rather than overly worrying about my grades. The weekly PSET helped me apply the information that I learned and helped me to retain it, and the structure of the midterm and final meant that I really understood the key concepts of this course.
The strength of this course is definitely the amount of support provided by the TAs and our professor.

Strengths: course material is diverse. Material covers extremely important and relevant topics like probability theories and why certain outcomes exist in a rational setting. Instructor clearly knowledgeable. Problem sets were directly related to material. 
Weaknesses: Consistent errors or glitches associated with problem sets created through Google form answers. Had difficulty in following some assignments like Gephi.
This course was very chill and easy. All our assignments are reasonable and doable. The final project was actually pretty fun to do.

Strength - ease
Weakness - material not that riveting

I think this course has a lot of potential, as network analysis can be extremely useful and cool. The course was very organized, but it would've helped if assignment expectations (especially the final project) were more clear. Also, I would've liked if the class went more in depth on deeper network analysis, rather than some of the other applications we looked at in the later weeks.
Strength is that homeworks and exams are fairly straight-forward. But there is somewhat of a gap between material taught in class and assignments.
The problem sets were not too hard but its difficult to know if you are doing it right or not
The course workload is very manageable.
nice that you had multiple trys on psets, office hours were helpful too

TFs beside the head TF are less knowledgeable than you and it shows. Bad at answering emails. The lectures also went all over the place and weren't engaging enough to actually have people excited to come listen to them. I feel bad, but at the same time, Coifman knows his class is a bit of a joke.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Recording the lectures was helpful so you can go back and look at portions that show up on the p-sets a week later.
virtual lecture was good!
all succeeded
I think the virtual group presentations over zoom  worked well
Good course for pandemic format
RECORDED LECTURE
Asynchronous learning if you wanted. Very helpful at times. The recorded lectures could be rewatched if you missed something.
Help with project could be improved
wasn't a great course or directed well at all
Recording the lectures was great, because it allowed me to be flexible in my schedule and return to certain lectures for revision purposes.
I think that given COVID restrictions, this course was designed in the best way possible!
having recorded lectures and exams open for multiple days was nice
I believe that having some student participation would have made class more fun to see how peers could have interpreted a scenario.
Virtual office hours worked out nicely, but virtual lectures did not include significant student engagement.
The live but recorded lectures were perfect
The group project was a good opportunity to interact with other students in the class

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you need a 6th credit
It's a great 6th class, super gutty
yes!!
This is a good math course for students who don't love math and need a QR credit. It is structured so you can succeed if calculus and higher levels of math are not your strong suit.
yes! take it! not bad at all work-wise, you can keep trying on psets until you get it correct which is great for learning the material
If you need a very low workload good QR then sure
Yes if you are looking for a QR credit - you do need a little math and coding knowledge though
If you need a QR gut, this is definitely the class to take. It is very little work and really easy to get an A.
For sure recommend if you're looking for an easy QR (particularly for non-STEM students)
Yes, if you want a lower workload QR, but it is not a gut at all
A lot of independent work
Yep, great course, especially if you struggle with math.
Yes! Especially if non-stem!
Absolutely
Yes
Best QR course at Yale!
Yes if you need an easy QR credit
Yes
sure, if they're looking for a light workload class

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to a non-STEM student looking to further their understanding of QR and networks. I so appreciated that this course was accessible for me, because as an English major there are so many QR courses that look interesting to me but that I know I would struggle through. It's amazing to have a course like this where I felt like I could succeed and the material was not too out of my depth but still challenging.
Yes, it's a great math credit and provides students with a new way to look at systems/networks.
yes! perfect QR gut for those that aren't great at math.
yes

I would recommend this course to non-STEM majors looking to learn more about probabilities, game theory and decision-making. Networks were an integral part of the final project and allowed me to learn a lot about frameworks and how to interpret data through networks.
I would recommend this class to any non-STEM student who is looking for a relatively easy QR credit that is interesting enough to keep them engaged.
yes
Yes! This a good class to take to get rid of your QR credit for non -stem majors! The psets were reasonable, and the final project was cool to work on
Yes if you need a gut or 5th credit
No. I had hoped to learn a little about networks beyond what I already knew (and I found the applications interesting), but I was not highly engaged with the class.
Yes I do recommend.
Yes it is a great Math credit
Yes!
yes - easy and the project is cool

Only for a QR credit, and even then it's not even worth it. The project is too much work for what it's worth and the psets don't actually really match much of the lecture materials. I stopped going for the last 5 weeks (or rather, watching the recordings) because it was a massive waste of my time.
